quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: This is a pattern with AI, I think, where you really have to ship to understand what is even possible and what people want, rather than being able to reason about that a priori. So, ChatGPT came together at the end because we just wanted the learnings as soon as we could.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: I've never ever worked on a product that is so empirical in its nature where, if you don't stop, and watch, and listen to what people are doing, you're going to miss so much. With AI, because so much of it is emergent, you actually really need to stop and listen after you launch something and then iterate on the things people are trying to do.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: I always felt like part of my role here, obviously, was to think about the direction of the product, but also to just set the pace and the resting heartbeat for our teams. And this is especially important when the only way to find out what people like and what's valuable is to bring it into the external world.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: As a thought exercise, I always like people asking, 'Okay, if this was the most important thing and you wanted to truly maximally accelerate it, what would you do?' That doesn't mean that you go do that, but it's really a good forcing function for understanding what's critical path versus what can happen later.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: I still feel like ChatGPT feels a little bit like MS-DOS, like we haven't built Windows yet. And it'll be obvious once we do, but there's something that feels a little bit like... Imagine MS-DOS had gone viral and you were just trying to hack little conversation starters onto it.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: I feel like we would have immense regret if you had a model that was state-of-the-art on health bench and you didn't use that to help people, you just disabled that use case because you wanted to avoid all possible downside. I think the duty is to make it awesome and to do the work, talk to experts, figure out how good it really is, where it breaks down, communicate that.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: One of them is that amazing ideas come from anywhere. The thing about running a research lab is you really don't tell people what to research. We inherited that culture even as we become a research and product company. So just letting people do things who have amazing ideas rather than being the gatekeeper or prioritizer of everything has been proven immensely valuable to us.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: If we're shipping a feature and it doesn't get 2X better as the model gets 2X smarter, it's probably not a feature we should be shipping. Not always true, but I think for many of the core capabilities, that's a good litmus test.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: It is a small team that is running ChatGPT. I take inspiration from WhatsApp where it was a very small team running a very global-scale product. And then more importantly, you have to treat hiring a little bit more like executive recruiting and less like just pure pipeline recruiting where you really need to understand what is the gap you're trying to fill on each team.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: If you are actually reasoning from scratch, is it better to wait until you got a polished product or to ship out something raw even if it makes less sense and start learning? I think a company with a lot of process will make one call. If you're first principles about it, you're like, 'You know what? We should ship. It's embarrassing, but that's strictly less bad than not getting the feedback you wanted.'

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: You're going to be polishing the wrong things in this space. You absolutely should polish things, but you won't know what to polish until after you ship. And I think that is uniquely true in an environment where the properties of your product are emergent and not knowable in advance.

quotes.speaker: Nick Turley
quotes.text: I feel like you could think of software development as, you could be a conductor of an orchestra or you could be in a jazz band. I love how in jazz you're riffing off of each other and you listen to what one person played and then you play something back. Great product development is like that, ideas could come from anywhere, it shouldn't be a scripted process.

takeaways: Ship to learn, not to finish: In AI product development, the properties of your product are emergent and not knowable in advance, so velocity is the primary tool for discovering what to build and polish.
Set the resting heartbeat: A product leader's job is to establish the pace of the organization, asking 'Why can't we do this now?' as a forcing function to separate critical path from noise.
Run towards hard use cases, not away: When your AI is state-of-the-art at something like health or relationship advice, the duty is to make it great rather than disable it out of risk aversion.

Build features that scale with model intelligence: If a feature doesn't get 2X better as the model gets 2X smarter, it may not be worth shipping -- AI-native products must compound with their underlying technology.
Small teams, big impact: Run lean like WhatsApp, treat hiring like executive recruiting to fill specific skill gaps, and empower people from any function to contribute product ideas.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the conventional wisdom that products need polish before shipping -- argues embarrassment from shipping raw is strictly less bad than not learning
Pushes back against the tech industry default of disabling risky use cases at scale -- argues the duty is to run towards high-stakes use cases like health and relationships, not away from them
Rejects the gatekeeper model of product leadership -- argues ideas should come from anywhere, inherited from research lab culture where you don't tell people what to research
